p: The ultraviolet–visible (UV–vis) spectrum of PD1-1 is shown in Figure 2A. PD1-1 showed no absorption at 260 and 280 nm, indicating the absence of protein. This was consistent with results of Bradford’s method. The FT-IR spectrum of PD1-1 was scanned in the range of 400–4000 cm −1, exhibiting a typical polysaccharide absorption peak. As shown in Figure 2B, the strong peak at 3431 cm −1 was attributed to O–H group stretching vibrations, the peak at around 2927 cm −1 was attributed to C–H group stretching vibrations, bands at 1637 and 1437 cm −1 were attributed to flexural vibrations of C=O groups, and the signal at 1031 cm −1 was attributed to C–O group stretching vibrations. The characteristic peaks at 935, 875, and 818 cm −1 were attributed to fructose with α-type and β-type glycosidic linkages simultaneously [ 18, 19]. These results confirmed that PD1-1 showed typical polysaccharide absorption peaks.
